results.title: Family history: getting started
results.creator_credit: Video Education Australasia and Geoff Russell
results.brief_description: Searching for clues to their ancestral past has become a popular hobby and pastime for many Australians. Featuring expert input from Frances Brown, (Genealogy and Local History - State Library of Victoria) this program demonstrates how to begin researching your family history. We look at why people seek the information, how they go about it, and the skills needed to complete an accurate family history project.
results.description: Searching for clues to their ancestral past has become a popular hobby and pastime for many Australians. results.title: Family Group
results.creator_credit: Dept of Film Production for the Dept of Agriculture, Norman Laird and Rodney Musch
results.brief_description: A sheep dog eats part of a dead sheep and spreads hydatid infection to a farmer’s family. Stresses need for constant vigilance against hydatids.

results.title: Family follies
results.creator_credit: Guidance Associates and Peter J Ketchum
results.brief_description: Uses a humorous skit with dances, songs, and production numbers in order to highlight the problems which trouble young people: communication with parents, developing responsibility and independence from parents, and learning to cope with competitive attitudes in the family. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Family foibles
results.creator_credit: Brian McKenzie, Steve Thomas and Flying Carpet Films
results.brief_description: A series of five, half-hour documentaries, made for television, that examine very different challenges facing five contemporary Australian families. The filmmakers’ methods range from strictly observational (fly-on-the-wall), to active involvement (where the director is a participant in the family’s drama). Each episode features a different family facing a turning point in its collective life, that forces family members to face challenges of love, loyalty and change, whether they are striving to find a place within one’s family, to keep a family together, to create a new family or to change an old one. A study guide is available from http://www.roninfilms.com.au/related/2365104851-0.pdf

results.title: Family down the Fraser
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, John Taylor and Tony Westman
results.brief_description: Richard and Rochelle Wright and their two sons travelled the Fraser River from Cache Tete Jaune to the Pacific coast in a rubber raft. In addition to being a great adventure, the trip brought them into contact with people who told them some of the history of the river, and acquainted them with lifestyles vastly different from their own citified ways.

results.title: Family day care [Greek version]
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Robin Hughes and Karl McPhee
results.brief_description: Designed to describe all aspects of the family Day Care Scheme, financed by the Department of Social Security, the film follows a co-ordinator of a scheme in the inner Sydney suburb Marackville. Through her day-to-day experiences we see different kinds of care being given to children’s differing needs and we see colourful experiences designed for the children by highly skilled care-givers. Cinematography by John Hosking. In Greek and English.

results.title: Family day care
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Robin Hughes and Karl McPhee
results.brief_description: Additional credits are: script- Karl McPhee; photographer- John Hosking; editor- Karl Sodersten; sound- Max Hensser, Julian Ellingworth. Pam Goodwin is one of the co-ordinators of a Family Day Care Program. Her job entails interviewing parents and helping them find the kind of care that they want for their children, and interviewing the women who want to mind children and helping them in this role.

results.title: Family Court
results.creator_credit: Peter Campbell, Diane Sundin, Family Court of Australia and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 58 of Series “English at work”.
This video explains the role of the Family Court in divorce cases. It explains the grounds for applying for divorce, and the issues involved in a divorce in Australia. It also explains options offered by the Family Court after an application for divorce has been made: the structure of Information sessions, conciliation conferences, and court counsellors to help resolve differences in the main areas of dispute; children and property.

results.title: Family circles
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Gudrun Parker, Tom Daly and Morten Parker
results.brief_description: Shows how the interplay of home and school influences the development of children. The experiences of three children illustrate vividly how parental indifference, lack of imagination, and emotional conflict at home can destroy the confidence and enthusiasm necessary for a child’s success at school. (Awards: Cleveland; Toronto; Montevideo)
